Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron said on Tuesday that he did not present any murder charges to the grand jury.  that was empaneled to hear the case of Breonna Taylor, the 26-year-old Black woman who was shot and killed by a trio of plainclothes Louisville police officers in her home back in March.  He never spoke about Breonna Taylor to the grand jury.  In a sit-down interview with local news station WDRB, Cameron said that his office found murder charges were not appropriate.  Really?  Murder charges were not appropriate, so he didn't bother talking to the grand jury about Breonna Taylor at all.  They're an independent body.  If they wanted to make an assessment about different charges, they could have done that, Cameron said.  Really?  These are regular American citizens.  They are not legal experts.  Oh, this man is dirty.  But our recommendation was that Officer Jonathan Mattingly and Miles Cosgrove were justified in their acts and conduct.  Even though Mattingly and Cosgrove were the officers that combined to shoot Taylor six times.  It was announced last week that the grand jury had decided not to press any charges against them.  The only charges that the grand jury decided upon were three cases of wanton endangerment for Officer Brett Hankinson.  Hankinson was fired from the force in June after it was found that he blindly shot 10 shots into Taylor's apartment.  Cameron noted, noted last week that there wasn't conclusive evidence of any of Hankinson's shots hit Taylor.  However, some of the bullets did travel into an adjacent apartment where three people unrelated to the case were, which is why Hankinson was indicted.  After her death, Taylor became a rally cry, say her name, for nationwide protests decrying police brutality and systematic racism that were spearheaded by a resurgence of Black Lives Matter movement.  Despite lawmakers, celebrities, and activists calling for the three officers to be arrested and charged for Taylor's death, ultimately none of them were directly held accountable.
